chapter.para: The ECB SBC v2 is a CPM compatible single board computer with large ROM drive and a battery backed up RAM drive, a parallel interface that could connect to a IDE hard drive-like device via an additional board, and a serial port to act as console.

The Theory of Operation cannot hope to fully explain the entire board, but at least some helpful notes will be provided. Generally this should aim to exceed a simple list of features, without going into design detail. A good analogy is there is a physical walkthru at the start of the construction section, this section is more of a conceptual or theoretical walkthru.
Typical format: Project part ID, quantity if not one, model name, commentary if any, suppliers listed by supplier, item number, approx qty 1 cost, supplier comment

14dip300 qty at least one IC socket
Socket pin type selection is a hotly contested personal choice.
Gold plate is less mechanically durable than tin, more corrosion resistant than the IC pins, and more expensive
Machined pins grip the pins more tightly, which is either considered a blessing or a curse, and cost more than folded sockets
The board aesthetically looks better if you use identical type sockets on the board, unless you're intentionally trying to highlight an area of the board.
In theory, you could use orange plastic sockets for the ECB interface, blue sockets for the memory decode logic...
Digikey part number AE10012-ND $0.79 on 2013-02-02 per VLM This is machined pin/tin
2-pin shorting plugs for configuration jumpers at least 15 or so
A female molex PC 5.25 floppy drive power connector (like off the end of a broken PC power supply cable)
I remove the yellow +12 volt wire from the connector as the SBC v2 does not use 12 volts
If you plan to run your board off an existing, working ECB backplane board, you do not need a socket on the SBCv2 or a separate power cable for the SBCv2
5x2 IDC female crimp on connector, a length of 10 conductor ribbor cable, a rs232 cable with a DB-9 connector
If this is your first N8VEM ECB project you probably need to build a compatible RS-232 cable to connect to a PC acting as a terminal
A 32 pin ZIF socket for the eprom, and several 32 pin machined sockets or some other way to mount the ZIF above the level of conflicting devices on the board
